intro: Sphalanthus pellegrinianus, commonly known as the Pellegrin's spurge, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in regions of Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family, which is characterized by its milky sap and often striking floral structures. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its small, yellowish flowers are clustered in complex inflorescences, and it produces capsules as its fruit type. Sphalanthus pellegrinianus is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological niche.
